items.title: Event Responses from Google Calendar Not Being Sent
items.body:
Hi everyone! First and foremost, thank you for your work on this library. I use it literally every day and am very appreciative that it's here and of your work...

I'm pretty sure this isn't a problem with icalendar but wanted to see if anyone here had had this same problem just in case it IS something I'm doing wrong (or, less likely, a bug) in icalendar.

Any suggestions would be very welcome...

I am writing to discuss a problem I'm seeing with sending ICS files generated using iCalendar to Google Calendar. I am using icalendar (latest version in python 3) to programmatically generate an ICS file and sending it to a Google Calendar user via email. Google Calendar is:
1. Showing the event as an event.
2. Showing the proper buttons (Yes, No, Maybe).
3. Clicking Yes, No, Maybe does correctly place the event into the Google Calendar.

HOWEVER, no response email is sent to the organizer. Ever.

I have:
1. Confirmed that the receiving google calendar DOES send proper responses to invites from other Google Calendar users and/or Microsoft Outlook users.
2. Confirmed that there are no responses hiding in the organizer's spam folder or otherwise.
3. Ensured that the same invite does trigger the same display (correctly) in Microsoft Outlook AND that Outlook correctly sends the response email back to the organizer.
4. Ensured that the FROM address on the email sent by the organizer matches the email address for the organizer.
5. Tried sending the email/invite from a Gmail account via Google SMTP and other accounts via AWS Simple Email Service.
6. I have attempted to "receive" the invite in Chrome (on Mac) and Safari (on Mac and iPhone).
7. Tried different responses (YES, NO, MAYBE) from the receiving google calendar.
8. Confirmed that the receiving google account's event responses are turned on.
9. Attempted it with multiple receiving gmail accounts.

All to no avail. The event response is never sent. The invite is properly formatted as far as I can tell by manual inspection and online validation tools for compliance with RFC 5545.

BUT STILL NO RESPONSE EMAILS ARE SENT IN RESPONSE TO THIS INVITE.

Is Google Calendar looking for some magic matching between something in the ICS and the wrapping email?

PLEASE HELP! I've been at this for five days without success.

Any help or suggestions anyone can offer would be very welcome.

Thank you very much.

Best,
Keyton


The iCalendar (RFC 5545 compliant) is as follows:

BEGIN:VCALENDAR
PRODID:MyProgram
VERSION:2.0
CALSCALE:GREGORIAN
METHOD:REQUEST
BEGIN:VEVENT
DTSTART:20181005T232614Z
DTEND:20181006T002614Z
DTSTAMP:20181004T232614Z
ORGANIZER;CN=organiser:mailto:testorganizer@gmail.com
UID:FIXMEUID20181004T232614Z
ATTENDEE;CUTYPE=INDIVIDUAL;ROLE=REQ-PARTICIPANT;PARTSTAT=NEEDS-ACTION;RSVP=TRUE
 ;CN=keyton@gmail.com;X-NUM-GUESTS=0:
 mailto:keyton@gmail.com
ATTENDEE;CUTYPE=INDIVIDUAL;ROLE=REQ-PARTICIPANT;PARTSTAT=NEEDS-ACTION;RSVP=TRUE
 ;CN=keyton.weissinger@workaddress.com;X-NUM-GUESTS=0:
 mailto:keyton.weissinger@workaddress.com
CREATED:20181004T232614Z
DESCRIPTION: test invitation from MyProg
LAST-MODIFIED:20181004T232614Z
LOCATION:
SEQUENCE:0
STATUS:CONFIRMED
SUMMARY:test 20181005 @ 23:26
TRANSP:OPAQUE

END:VCALENDAR

items.title: Empty feed fails validation
items.body:
Thanks to rfc5545 3.4 https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5545#page-50 a calendar must contain at least one object. So when we have an empty icalendar object it fails validation.

But if a calendar truly doesn't have any events, how are we meant to offer a feed that validates?

For example an empty/basic calendar looks like:

```
BEGIN:VCALENDAR
VERSION:2.0
PRODID:-//Bookings Calendar//example.com//8690841
END:VCALENDAR
```

But that fails validation with some icalendar readers. What's the correct thing to do in this situation.

items.title: UnicodeEncodeError if TZID parameter is non-ascii
items.body:
```python
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
from icalendar import Calendar
from datetime import datetime
import pytz

ics = u"""BEGIN:VCALENDAR
METHOD:REQUEST
PRODID:Microsoft Exchange Server 2010
VERSION:2.0
BEGIN:VTIMEZONE
TZID:(UTC-03:00) Brasília
BEGIN:STANDARD
DTSTART:16010101T235959
TZOFFSETFROM:-0200
TZOFFSETTO:-0300
RRULE:FREQ=YEARLY;INTERVAL=1;BYDAY=3SA;BYMONTH=2
END:STANDARD
BEGIN:DAYLIGHT
DTSTART:16010101T235959
TZOFFSETFROM:-0300
TZOFFSETTO:-0200
RRULE:FREQ=YEARLY;INTERVAL=1;BYDAY=2SA;BYMONTH=10
END:DAYLIGHT
END:VTIMEZONE
BEGIN:VEVENT
ORGANIZER:MAILTO:b@example.com
ATTENDEE:MAILTO:a@example.com
DESCRIPTION;LANGUAGE=pt-BR:something something
UID:something
SUMMARY;LANGUAGE=pt-BR:Something
DTSTART;TZID=\"(UTC-03:00) Brasília\":20170511T133000
DTEND;TZID=\"(UTC-03:00) Brasília\":20170511T140000
CLASS:PUBLIC
PRIORITY:5
DTSTAMP:20170509T131359Z
TRANSP:OPAQUE
STATUS:CONFIRMED
SEQUENCE:0
END:VEVENT
END:VCALENDAR"""

cal = Calendar.from_ical(ics)
dtstart = cal.walk(name='VEVENT')[0].decoded("DTSTART")
expected = pytz.timezone('America/Sao_Paulo').localize(datetime(2017, 5, 11, 13, 30))
assert dtstart == expected
```

Currently fails with an error due to the timezone TZID parameter having a non-ASCII character:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/tmp/t.py", line 42, in <module>
    cal = Calendar.from_ical(tz)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/icalendar/cal.py", line 347, in from_ical
    _timezone_cache[component['TZID']] = component.to_tz()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/icalendar/cal.py", line 555, in to_tz
    zone = str(self['TZID'])
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\xed' in position 16: ordinal not in range(128)
```

I think the ICS in question is valid. RFC5545 defines the TZID value as `paramtext` which includes non-ascii characters.

To fix, I think it's sufficient to do `zone = self['TZID'].encode('ascii', 'replace')` in `Timezone.to_tz()`. zone is used as the timezone name and the name of the `DstTzInfo` subclass. As such it's just informational. The full unicode TZID should continue to be used as the `_timezone_cache` key. I think `tzname = str(component['TZNAME'])` should similarly be fixed. Could also consider using `unicodedata.normalize` to create an ascii version of the TZID string.

What do you think? I'm happy to submit a pull request

items.title: Maintenance / my role in this project
items.body:
I seem to be the most active maintainer of this project at the moment,
which is fine by me, but as I'm hesitant to merge my own PRs (as this
isn't my project and I feel for community projects such as this, whoever
works on a PR shouldn't also be merging it), bugs get fixed very slowly.
New features, especially backwards compatibility breaking ones obviously
get merged even slower, if they are getting worked on at all.

If nobody has time to review at least the bug fixing PRs, it would
perhaps be better if I did at least merge bug fixing PRs (and you don't
shout too loudly at me if I break anything)?

Other maintainers, what are your opinions?

items.title: Can not attach binary file
items.body:
I'm trying to attach a binary file (in this case à PDF) to a VEVENT with the code



```
import io
import os
import icalendar

nm = u'c:/Temp/temp.pdf'
f = io.FileIO(nm, "rb")
data = f.readall()                        
f.close()
                        
cal = icalendar.Calendar()
event = icalendar.Event()
event.add('summary', 'Test Attachment')
file = icalendar.vBinary(data)
file.params['X-FILENAME']=os.path.basename(nm)
event.add('attach', file)
cal.add_component(event)
```
but this doesn't not work as the vBinary class calls "encode('utf-8')" on the binary data which fails and then falls back to "encode('utf-8','replace')" which modifies the binary data !! I can work around this with the code

```
import io
import os
import icalendar

nm = u'c:/Temp/temp.pdf'
f = io.FileIO(nm, "rb")
data = f.readall()                        
f.close()
                        
cal = icalendar.Calendar()
event = icalendar.Event()
event.add('summary', 'Test Attachment')

# FIXME 
# file = icalendar.vBinary(data)
data64 = binascii.b2a_base64(data)[:-1]
file = icalendar.prop.vInline(data64)
file.params['ENCODING'] = 'BASE64'
file.params['VALUE'] = 'BINARY'
# \FIXME

file.params['X-FILENAME']=os.path.basename(nm)
event.add('attach', file)
cal.add_component(event)
```

Any chance of a bug fix ? Or failing that what is the recommended way of attaching a binary file to a VEVENT ?

David

items.title: Instance vs. list of instances when accessing a property
items.body:
I just want to confirm, it seems that when you retrieve a property, you might get an instance of that property or a list of instances. Here is one example:

``` python
>>> Calendar.from_ical('BEGIN:VCALENDAR\nATTENDEE:MAILTO:a@b.c\nATTENDEE:MAILTO:d@e.f\nEND:VCALENDAR')['ATTENDEE']
[vCalAddress('MAILTO:a@b.c'), vCalAddress('MAILTO:d@e.f')]
>>> Calendar.from_ical('BEGIN:VCALENDAR\nATTENDEE:MAILTO:a@b.c\nEND:VCALENDAR')['ATTENDEE']
vCalAddress('MAILTO:a@b.c')
```

So, accessing `ATTENDEE` can give you one instance or a list of instances. Is this the case?

If so, the user has to check the type of the result and determine whether to iterate over it or just access it. Is this intentional?

items.title: Wheel support
items.body:
http://pythonwheels.com/

Right now, only the `tar.gz` file is being distributed on PyPI for [icalendar](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/icalendar), which isn't _that much_ of an issue, but it does add some time to installing the package.

This package should be compatible with the Wheel format, considering it doesn't appear to have any C dependencies and it is compatible with both Python 2 and 3. As a result, you should only need to generate a universal wheel and then everyone (on all systems) will get the ability to install icalendar with just the wheel, without having to do any extra work.

items.title: parameters with binary values including =
items.body:
We currently do not support VEVENTS with binary (hex-encoded) parameter-values (ending in `==`) like this:

```
BEGIN:VEVENT
DTSTART:20130416T100000Z
DTEND:20130416T110000Z
DTSTAMP:20130416T092616Z
UID:123
SUMMARY:wichtiger termin 1
X-APPLE-STRUCTURED-LOCATION;X-BINARY=abc==:geo:48.206686,16.363235
END:VEVENT
```

I'm not really sure that's allowed, I'll have to have a another look in the RFC, but I believe we should support it anyway, because Apple seems to produce those VEVENTs, see geier/khal#467

items.title: datetime values of length 15 fail to parse
incompatible changes in 3.9.2
items.body:
With 70a7b5a16748afbf0d48ca180c2b7613fdd7e7d0 we introduced some  backwards incompatible changes:
- `Component.is_broken` got replaced with `Component.errors`
- events with a `RDATE;VALUE=PERIOD:19970101T180000Z/19970102T070000Z,19970109T180000Z/PT5H30M` component still had an `RDATE` with `VALUE=PERIOD` param before, now they are `RDATE:None`

While I do agree with both changes, I think they should have been deferred to the 4.0.0 release. Because we don't have `VALUE=PERIOD` anyway I think we can leave this one as it is, but I believe we should bring back `Component.is_broken` for the 3.9.3 release.

items.title: Invalid/unknown component name being substituted during parsing
items.body:
Hi,

I encountered a strange behavior in a case where there are invalid component names in an iCalendar string.

``` python
>>> # the following probably shouldn't pass
>>> vcal = icalendar.Calendar.from_ical('BEGIN:THISWRONG\nSTRANGEPROP:12345\nEND:THISWRONG')
>>> # but it did
>>> vcal.to_ical()
'BEGIN:VCALENDAR\r\nSTRANGEPROP:12345\r\nEND:VCALENDAR\r\n'
```

As you can see, the parser accepted the component "THISWRONG" without any warning/error. On top of that, it represents it as a VCALENDAR component instead. This does not seem to be a correct behavior at all. It is caused by:

https://github.com/collective/icalendar/blob/master/src/icalendar/cal.py#L328

Also notice the property "STRANGEPROP" from the example. The case here is similar as "STRANGEPROP" is definitely not defined in iCalendar RFC. At least here it stays the same "STRANGEPROP" property, though.

I understand that this behavior might be there for the sake of extensibility, but at least in the first case it is not handled correctly at all. Perhaps a pluggable interface would help here but until then at least the first case should be fixed.

Opinions/comments are welcome :)

items.title: Typo and discrepancies with RFC ?
items.body:
I am not python expert neither a developer but for a small personnal project I looked at icalendar project. I am not 100% sure if my findings are relevant. My comments are related to ical.ics:
- in class Event(Component), the class variable singletons shows twice the property 'DTSTART'. Should not be an issue.
- in class FreeBusy(Component), the class variable singletons shows a property 'DURATION', as far as I can see in the RFC, this property is not applicable to VFREEBUSY component?
- in classes, TimezoneStandard(Component) and TimezoneDaylight(Component), the property 'EXDATE' is not specified, while it seems to be specified in RFC?
- in class Alarm(Component), the property 'DESCRIPTION' is missing, while it seems to be specified in RFC?
- In various classes, One could see the 'EXRULE' property which seems to be outdated in the RFC. Maybe it is for backward compatibility.

items.title: Parsing invalid icalendars fails without any warning
items.body:
Example:

``` python
import icalendar

event_str = """
BEGIN:VCALENDAR
BEGIN:VEVENT
DTEND:20150905T100000Z
DTSTART:20150905T090000Z
X-APPLE-RADIUS=49.91307046514149
UID:123
END:VEVENT
END:VCALENDAR
"""

calendar = icalendar.Calendar.from_ical(event_str)
print(calendar.to_ical())
```

returns

```
BEGIN:VCALENDAR
END:VCALENDAR
```

but probably should throw an exception or at least a warning instead of ignoring the invalid VEVENT silently. Also see https://github.com/geier/khal/issues/294 .

items.title: PERCENT property in VTODO should be PERCENT-COMPLETE
items.body: According to [RFC 2445](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2445#section-4.8.1.8) and also its successor [RFC 5545](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5545#section-3.8.1.8), the property denoting the completeness of a todo item is named `PERCENT-COMPLETE` but icalendar currently has a property `PERCENT` listed in the singletons list of the Todo component.

items.title: No timezone info on EXDATE
items.body:
When an EXDATE is parsed, it does not retain timezone information. I believe the same may happen with RDATE fields.

For example, take the following iCal feed:

```
BEGIN:VCALENDAR
PRODID:-//Google Inc//Google Calendar 70.9054//EN
VERSION:2.0
CALSCALE:GREGORIAN
METHOD:PUBLISH
X-WR-CALNAME:Market East
X-WR-TIMEZONE:America/New_York
X-WR-CALDESC:
BEGIN:VTIMEZONE
TZID:America/New_York
X-LIC-LOCATION:America/New_York
BEGIN:DAYLIGHT
TZOFFSETFROM:-0500
TZOFFSETTO:-0400
TZNAME:EDT
DTSTART:19700308T020000
RRULE:FREQ=YEARLY;BYMONTH=3;BYDAY=2SU
END:DAYLIGHT
BEGIN:STANDARD
TZOFFSETFROM:-0400
TZOFFSETTO:-0500
TZNAME:EST
DTSTART:19701101T020000
RRULE:FREQ=YEARLY;BYMONTH=11;BYDAY=1SU
END:STANDARD
END:VTIMEZONE

BEGIN:VEVENT
DTSTART;TZID=America/New_York:20130907T120000
DTEND;TZID=America/New_York:20130907T170000
RRULE:FREQ=WEEKLY;BYDAY=FR,SA;UNTIL=20131025T035959Z
EXDATE;TZID=America/New_York:20131012T120000
EXDATE;TZID=America/New_York:20131011T120000
DTSTAMP:20131021T025552Z
UID:ak30b02u7858q1oo6ji9dm4mgg@google.com
CREATED:20130903T181453Z
DESCRIPTION:The Fieldhouse and Hard Rock Cafe are working with PhillyRising
  to provide live entertainment on Friday and Saturday afternoons throughout
  the Summer.
LAST-MODIFIED:20131015T210927Z
LOCATION:12th and Market Streets (weather permitting)
SEQUENCE:0
STATUS:CONFIRMED
SUMMARY:Market East Live!
TRANSP:OPAQUE
END:VEVENT

END:VCALENDAR
```

The DTSTART and DTEND fields both will have tzinfo when converted to datetimes (`ev['DTSTART'].dt`), but the EXDATEs will not (`ev['EXDATE'][0].dts[0].dt`).

items.title: event.add("geo") only accepts tuples
items.body:
A ValueError is raised when adding coordinates to an event using event.add("geo", coordinates), given that coordinates is a list instead of a tuple. 

So this will work:

```
event.add("geo", (41.9000, 12.500))
```

But this won't:

```
event.add("geo", [41.9000, 12.500])
```

I don't know if this is a design decision, but it was not really obvious to me and I would argue that any iterable with two items should do.

The following script will trigger the error:

```
import pytz

from datetime import datetime
from icalendar import Calendar, Event

cal = Calendar()
cal.add('prodid', '-//My calendar product//mxm.dk//')
cal.add('version', '2.0')

event = Event()
event.add('summary', 'Python meeting about calendaring')
event.add('dtstart', datetime(2005, 4, 4, 8, 0, 0, tzinfo=pytz.utc))
event.add('dtend', datetime(2005, 4, 4, 10, 0, 0, tzinfo=pytz.utc))
event.add('dtstamp', datetime(2005, 4, 4, 0, 10, 0, tzinfo=pytz.utc))
event.add('geo', [41.9000, 12.500])
event['uid'] = '20050115T101010/27346262376@mxm.dk'
event.add('priority', 5)

cal.add_component(event)
cal.to_ical()
```

items.title: A unicode data type for a event parameter results in "UnicodeDecodeError"
items.body:
With version 3.2 I did the following
Steps to repeat:

``` python
from icalendar import Calendar, Event

cal = Calendar()
event = Event()
event.add(u'DESCRIPTION', u'äöüßÄÖÜ')
cal.add_component(event)

c = cal.to_ical()
```

Result:

``` shell
ValueError: Property: u'DESCRIPTION' Wrong values "Parameters({})" or "'\xc3\xa4\xc3\xb6\xc3\xbc\xc3\x9f\xc3\x84\xc3\x96\xc3\x9c'"
```

With version 3.1 I can not reproduce the issue.

The exception is coming from a line in `parser.py` of method `from_parts` class `Contentline`

``` python
return Contentline('%s:%s' %  (name, values))
```

From my point of view it seems an accident after solving #64.

Running the unit test `icalendar.tests.test_encoding` results in no problem.
A closer look at the test to search for the differences between the test and my use case revealed the following:
- Test: `event.add("summary", u"åäö")`
- Use case: `event.add(u'DESCRIPTION' , u'äöüßÄÖÜ')`

So it seems the unicode data type for a parameter name is not further supported.
Proof: changing the unit test to my use case results in the error.

Simple workaround: remove all unicode occurrences of the parameter names (u"xy" -> "xy").

items.title: It is illegal to have a double quote character inside parameter values
items.body:
```
# coding: utf-8

import icalendar

content = """\
BEGIN:VCALENDAR
VERSION:2.0
PRODID:-//Apple Inc.//iCal 5.0.1//EN
CALSCALE:GREGORIAN
BEGIN:VEVENT
END:VEVENT
END:VCALENDAR
"""

cal = icalendar.Calendar.from_ical(content)
attendee = icalendar.vCalAddress('test-cal@bk.ru')
attendee.params['PARTSTAT'] = 'DECLINED'
attendee.params['CN'] = "Арамис\", д’Аламеда"
cal.subcomponents[0].add('ATTENDEE', attendee)
print cal.to_ical()
```

Result:

```
BEGIN:VCALENDAR
VERSION:2.0
PRODID:-//Apple Inc.//iCal 5.0.1//EN
CALSCALE:GREGORIAN
BEGIN:VEVENT
ATTENDEE;CN="Арамис", д’Аламеда";PARTSTAT=DECLINED:test-ca
 l@bk.ru
END:VEVENT
END:VCALENDAR
```

Note the CN parameter.

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3014137/can-should-ical-property-parametrs-be-escaped

It is illegal to have a double quote " character inside parameter values, so they should be deleted (or otherwise removed from the parameter value).

What do you think?

items.title: vDatetime.to_ical() fails with datetime parsed from dateutil
items.body:
```
In [1]: from dateutil import parser

In [2]: dt = parser.parse("2012-04-06T16:00:00Z")

In [3]: dt
Out[3]: datetime.datetime(2012, 4, 6, 16, 0, tzinfo=tzutc())

In [4]: from icalendar import vDatetime

In [5]: vDatetime(dt).to_ical()
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-5-8ae054a75fb5> in <module>()
----> 1 vDatetime(dt).to_ical()

/home/vic/projects/.venv/calendar/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/icalendar/prop.py in to_ical(self)
    556     def to_ical(self):
    557         dt = self.dt
--> 558         tzid = dt.tzinfo and dt.tzinfo.zone or None
    559         s = "%04d%02d%02dT%02d%02d%02d" % (
    560             self.dt.year,

AttributeError: 'tzutc' object has no attribute 'zone'
```

`dateutil` has it's own tzinfo implementation, which does not have `zone` attribute.
This should fix the problem:

```
diff --git a/src/icalendar/prop.py b/src/icalendar/prop.py
index 9fe980c..50391d1 100644
--- a/src/icalendar/prop.py
+++ b/src/icalendar/prop.py
@@ -555,7 +555,7 @@ class vDatetime:

     def to_ical(self):
         dt = self.dt
-        tzid = dt.tzinfo and dt.tzinfo.zone or None
+        tzid = dt.tzinfo.tzname(self.dt) if dt.tzinfo else None
         s = "%04d%02d%02dT%02d%02d%02d" % (
             self.dt.year,
             self.dt.month,
@@ -778,7 +778,7 @@ class vPeriod:

         self.params = Parameters()
         # set the timezone identifier
-        tzid = start.tzinfo and start.tzinfo.zone or None
+        tzid = start.tzinfo.tzname(start) if start.tzinfo else None
         if tzid:
             self.params['TZID'] = tzid
```

items.title: DATE-TIME property formatting
items.body:
I'm not clear on why `vDatetime` properties (such as `DTSTART`) use the `VALUE=DATE-TIME:` syntax:

```
DTSTART;TZID=Europe/Vienna;VALUE=DATE-TIME:20101010T100000
```

[RFC 5545 Section 3.3.5](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5545#section-3.3.5) describes a simpler (and more commonly used?) Date-Time format:

```
   DTSTART:19970714T133000                   ; Local time
   DTSTART:19970714T173000Z                  ; UTC time
   DTSTART;TZID=America/New_York:19970714T133000
                                             ; Local time and time
                                             ; zone reference
```

Mac OS X's Calendar.app doesn't appear to like the former but will accept the latter.

items.title: vDDDTypes.to_ical() fails if underlying datetime contains certain tzid
items.body:
When parsing an isoformatted date using `dateutil.parser`, the parsed `datetime` instance apparently contains timezone info that is not compatible to icalendar's `to_ical()`. I can imagine timezones are a big pain, but it shouldn't fail completely if there is a valid `datetime` instance given (in case of `dateutil.parser`, you don't even have an influence on how the timezone info looks like). 

See below for a minimal example to reproduce the issue:

``` python
>>> import icalendar
>>> import dateutil.parser
>>> date = dateutil.parser.parse('2012-08-30T22:41:00Z')
>>> date
datetime.datetime(2012, 8, 30, 22, 41, tzinfo=tzutc())
>>> icalendar.vDDDTypes(date)
<icalendar.prop.vDDDTypes instance at 0x28c6290>
>>> icalendar.vDDDTypes(date).to_ical()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/icalendar-3.0.1b2-py2.7.egg/icalendar/prop.py", line 431, in to_ical
    return vDatetime(dt).to_ical()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/icalendar-3.0.1b2-py2.7.egg/icalendar/prop.py", line 540, in to_ical
    tzid = dt.tzinfo and dt.tzinfo.zone or None
AttributeError: 'tzutc' object has no attribute 'zone'
>>> 
```

items.title: to_ical() fails if uid set is unicode
items.body:
If an event uid is a unicode string (even if it doesn't contain unicode characters) the call to_ical fails with the following error:

```
ValueError: Property: 'UID' Wrong values "Parameters({})" or "u'your_uid'"
```

To fix this you need to import StringTypes from types module and change parser.py line 447 from:

``` python
if values and not isinstance(values, str):
```

to:

``` python
if values and not isinstance(values, StringTypes):
```

items.title: TZID on UTC DATE-TIMEs
items.body:
According to RFC 2445: "The TZID property parameter MUST NOT be applied to DATE-TIME or TIME properties whose time values are specified in UTC."

But the module will produce them in cases like: 

``` python
e = Event()
e.add('dtstart', pytz.utc.localize(datetime.datetime.now()))
print e.to_ical()
```

Output:

```
BEGIN:VEVENT
DTSTART;TZID=UTC;VALUE=DATE-TIME:20120716T121830Z
END:VEVENT
```

items.title: iTip message icalendar.Calendar.walk() does not lead to VEVENT
items.body:
Using icalendar 3.0.1 beta 2, the following iTip mime multipart message part:

```
BEGIN:VCALENDAR
VERSION:2.0
PRODID:-//Roundcube Webmail 0.9-0.3.el6.kolab_3.0//NONSGML Calendar//EN
CALSCALE:GREGORIAN
METHOD:REQUEST
BEGIN:VEVENT
UID:626421779C777FBE9C9B85A80D04DDFA-A4BF5BBB9FEAA271
DTSTAMP:20120713T1254140
DTSTART;TZID=Europe/London:20120713T100000
DTEND;TZID=Europe/London:20120713T110000
SUMMARY:test
DESCRIPTION:test
ORGANIZER;CN="Doe, John":mailto:john.doe@example.org
ATTENDEE;ROLE=REQ-PARTICIPANT;PARTSTAT=NEEDS-ACTION;RSVP=TRUE:mailto:resourc
 e-collection-car@example.org
RRULE:FREQ=WEEKLY;INTERVAL=1;BYDAY=FR;
TRANSP:OPAQUE
END:VEVENT
END:VCALENDAR
```

when loaded with;

```
calendar = icalendar.Calendar.from_ical(itip_payload)
```

does not let;

``` python
for c in calendar.walk():
    if c.name == "VEVENT":
        # Do the actual event related stuff
```

get to any actual event.

c.subcomponents is an empty list, calendar.to_ical() doesn't include the event, and the only c.property_items() one gets are the properties to the VCALENDAR - never the VEVENT.

The only thing I seem to be able to get to is the VCALENDAR and its properties, but not its subcomponents, suggesting something is wrong with the stack / components hierarchy.

items.title: Parse error on utc-offset with seconds value
items.body:
Hello, icalendar broke on some ics files that I have.

It was choking on values like this:

BEGIN:STANDARD
DTSTART:18831118T120702
RDATE:18831118T120702
TZNAME:PST
TZOFFSETFROM:-075258
TZOFFSETTO:-0800
END:STANDARD

This is part of a Los Angeles time zone definition. It turns out this is allowed by RFC 5545:

time-numzone = ("+" / "-") time-hour time-minute [time-second]

It allows a slightly cleaner entrance from the time when time zones were by city. Anyway, it is a small patch to fix it, which I'll attach here presently. (I didn't make any tests, but the above example (-075258) should cover it nicely.)

``` python
--- prop.py.org 2011-02-09 06:31:47.000000000 +0100
+++ prop.py 2012-07-09 17:23:02.221750323 +0200
@@ -1317,8 +1317,14 @@
     def from_ical(ical):
         "Parses the data format from ical text format"
         try:
-            sign, hours, minutes = (ical[-5:-4], int(ical[-4:-2]), int(ical[-2:]))
-            offset = timedelta(hours=hours, minutes=minutes)
+       if len(ical) == 5:
+                sign, hours, minutes = (ical[-5:-4], int(ical[-4:-2]), int(ical[-2:]))
+                offset = timedelta(hours=hours, minutes=minutes)
+            elif len(ical) == 7:
+                sign, hours, minutes, seconds = (ical[-7:-6], int(ical[-6:-4]), int(ical[-4:-2]), int(ical[-2:]))
+                offset = timedelta(hours=hours, minutes=minutes, seconds=seconds)
+       else:
+           raise ValueError, 'Expected utc offset, got: %s' % ical
         except:
             raise ValueError, 'Expected utc offset, got: %s' % ical
         if offset >= timedelta(hours=24):
```

items.title: Suggest adding link to readthedocs to the README
ignores VTIMEZONE
items.body:
If an iCal file has something like:    (this is from Outlook 2010)

```
BEGIN:VTIMEZONE
TZID:Eastern Standard Time
BEGIN:STANDARD
DTSTART:16011104T020000
RRULE:FREQ=YEARLY;BYDAY=1SU;BYMONTH=11
TZOFFSETFROM:-0400
TZOFFSETTO:-0500
END:STANDARD
BEGIN:DAYLIGHT
DTSTART:16010311T020000
RRULE:FREQ=YEARLY;BYDAY=2SU;BYMONTH=3
TZOFFSETFROM:-0500
TZOFFSETTO:-0400
END:DAYLIGHT
END:VTIMEZONE
```

individual events are supposed to be able to reference it by name, by TZID:

```
DTSTART;TZID="Eastern Standard Time":20120130T100000
```

instead, this package depends entirely on pytz for timezone lookup, ignoring timezones that are defined in the file.
